item.title: Afghanistan: Final UK troops leave Kabul
item.description: Boris Johnson says the armed forces can be proud as Britain's 20-year military presence in the country ends.

item.title: Afghanistan: Biden says another Kabul airport attack likely
item.description: The US president says commanders have told him another attack could happen within the next 36 hours.

item.title: Herat under the Taliban: residents on the new rulers
item.description: People in Afghanistanâ€™s third-largest city, Herat, explain how life has changed in recent weeks.

item.title: Hurricane Ida: Thousands flee as storm bears down on Louisiana
item.description: Ida is forecast to be one of the strongest storms to hit Louisiana in 150 years.

item.title: Government plans to lift football standing ban
item.description: Some clubs will trial designated safe standing areas before the end of the season, the BBC understands.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Great Britain's Hannah Cockroft wins third successive 100m gold
item.description: Great Britain's Hannah Cockroft sets a new world record to win her third consecutive T34 100m crown and claims a stunning sixth Paralympic title, as GB win eight medals - including four golds - in a superb start to day five in Tokyo.

item.title: Brazil's Jair Bolsonaro says he will be killed, arrested or re-elected
item.description: Brazil's right-wing president is trying to rally support ahead of next year's election.

item.title: Europe migrant crisis: More than 500 people rescued off Italian island
item.description: Italian coastguards rescue 539 people from a small fishing boat believed to have set off from Libya.

item.title: Covid: Report finds big rises in garden furniture prices
item.description: Consumer group Which? says one retailer raised the price of a shed by 155% during the past two years.

item.title: Fire crews tackle blaze at Nick Nairn restaurant
item.description: More than 30 firefighters are called to a fire in the kitchen of Nick's in Bridge of Allan, near Stirling.

item.title: Players should get Covid jabs, says Andy Murray
item.description: Andy Murray says tennis players have a responsibility to the public as they travel the world, and should therefore be vaccinated against Covid.

item.title: Royal College of Nursing moves conference online after sex harassment claims
item.description: The Royal College of Nursing says its annual meeting in Liverpool will be replaced by virtual events.

item.title: Manchester City 5-0 Arsenal: Gunners suffer third league defeat in a row
item.description: Arsenal's miserable start to the new Premier League campaign continues as the Gunners are beaten 5-0 by Manchester City.

item.title: The Papers: UK out of Afghanistan and blame game erupts
item.description: The Sunday papers focus on the fallout from the end of the UK evacuation mission in Kabul.

item.title: 'We were hurt in bombs through no fault of our own'
item.description: Jennifer McNern lost both her legs and Margaret Yeaman was blinded in separate IRA bomb attacks.

item.title: Stormzy, Skepta and Aitch: Making beats for rap stars at 19
item.description: Chris Rich has made thousands from creating beats in the style of hip hop's elite.

item.title: Sabyasachi Mukherjee: Wanderlust collection was about India
item.description: Indian fashion designer Sabyasachi Mukherjee was criticised after he teamed up with high street retailer H&M.

item.title: Shannon Singh: â€˜People say I don't look Indian enough'
item.description: The former Love Island contestant speaks about the online abuse sheâ€™s received.

item.title: Afghan refugee heading to UK gives birth at 30,000 feet
item.description: Soman Noori gives birth to baby girl Havva while flying to Birmingham, with no doctor on board.

item.title: Back to the mosh pit: What it means for super-fans
item.description: Live music is back - and for the most committed fans it's the return of an entire way of life.

item.title: Why pigeons mean peril for satellite broadband
item.description: Satellite internet is a key part of plans to fill broadband "not spots", but simple things can affect it.

item.title: Agnes Sithole: The woman who fought South Africa's sexist marriage laws
item.description: Agnes Sithole became an unlikely hero after her husband of nearly 50 years tried to sell their home.

item.title: How lockdown puppies led to the rise of doggy day care
item.description: As owners return to the office or seek to socialise their pups, day care for dogs is taking off.

item.title: What are the holiday rules for travel to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: A traffic light system is in place setting out rules for entering the UK

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The progress made in vaccinating the country's adult population, as nearly 48 million people have received at least one dose.

item.title: Root 'proud' to set England Test wins record as captain
item.description: Joe Root is "proud" to set a new record for the number of Test wins as England captain and pays tribute to the players that helped him do it.

item.title: Rangers v Celtic: What are the key battlegrounds in '50/50' Old Firm derby?
item.description: With Rangers and Celtic set to go head to head in the first Old Firm derby of the season, BBC Scotland looks at the key issues that may decide the clash.

item.title: West Ham sign Zouma from Chelsea for Â£29.8m
item.description: West Ham sign France centre-back Kurt Zouma from Chelsea on a four-year deal for Â£29.8m.

item.title: Thompson-Herah continues stunning 100m form with victory in Paris
item.description: Jamaica's Elaine Thompson-Herah wins the 100m at the Diamond League meet in Paris in 10.72 seconds with Britain's Dina Asher-Smith third.

item.title: Match of the Day analysis: How 'shambolic' Arsenal were beaten by Manchester City
item.description: Match of the Day's Gary Lineker, Alan Shearer and Micah Richards look at Arsenal's 'shambolic' performance against Manchester City, including Granit Xhaka's red card.

item.title: Afghanistan: Black Hawks and Humvees - military kit now with the Taliban
item.description: As the insurgents swept through Afghanistan they inherited an arsenal of American-made equipment.

item.title: Afghanistan: 'I helped the US military, now help me save my family'
item.description: Afghans living in Texas plead for help to save the lives of loved ones left behind in Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghanistan: Shukria Barakzai's whispered voice notes and dramatic escape
item.description: The desperate messages sent by Afghan politician Shukria Barakzai to a UK MP. as the Taliban tried to hunt her down.

item.title: Afghanistan: The local people helping refugees in the UK
item.description: "No-one chooses to be a refugee, if any of us were in that position I hope we would get support."

item.title: Victims' relatives still desperately search for news of loved ones
item.description: The BBC's Secunder Kermani reports on the human cost of the Kabul airport attack.

item.title: Paralympic cheats stopped me winning gold
item.description: British swimmer Dan Pepper says his career was ruined by the ban on intellectual impairment sports at the Paralympics after a cheating scandal in 2000.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Who are Great Britain's medal winners?
item.description: A list of the Great Britain medal winners from the Tokyo 2020 Paralympics.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics medal table - which country has won most golds?
item.description: Which country is leading the medal table for the Tokyo 2020 Paralympics? How are Great Britain getting on?

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: What you need to know about Paralympic classification
item.description: From KL1 to PT2 and F11 to SB6 - everything you need to know about classification at the Paralympic Games.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Sport-by-sport guide
item.description: Twenty-two sports will feature in the Tokyo Paralympics - find out more about them all here.

item.title: Bilal Sarwary: 'The plane hit the tower and all our lives changed'
item.description: Afghan journalist Bilal Sarwary was selling carpets when 9/11 happened. From that day on, everything changed.

item.title: Shot in the head in Angola, left for dead, now a Wetherspoons star
item.description: Cesar Kimbirima fled Angola after being shot four times and spending five months in a coma.

item.title: Michael Knighton: The man who could have bought Man Utd for Â£10m but walked away
item.description: In August 1989, Michael Knighton celebrated his Manchester United takeover deal at Old Trafford. But the plotting against him had just begun.

item.title: India's living dead: 'They stared at me like I was a ghost'
item.description: If you're dead you can't own land - so if someone obtains your death certificate you could lose everything.

item.title: Peter Karlsson: The painful verdict on Swedish ice hockey player's 1995 killing
item.description: Peter Karlsson was stabbed to death in the street. His killer said he was protecting himself - via the so-called 'gay panic' defence.
